Creators.ConcatDisplayName: Yovannes, son of Chanipek and Et'ar (Armenian, Armenian)

Description: This Gospel Book, with richly painted Evangelist portraits, canon tables, and marginal illuminations, was made in Armenia in the early seventeenth century. An extensive colophon reveals that it was commissioned by a woman named Napat' as a memorial for herself and her family, and the book was consequently given by her to the Church of St. Sargis in Amida. The illuminator of the manuscript, Hovannes, was one of the most prolific among the artists and scribes at the Amida scriptorium. On the present codex he worked with the scribe Melk'on. Known collaborators, Hovannes and Melk'on executed a number of codices together.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Treasures in Heaven: Armenian Illuminated Manuscripts
Exhibitions.Textblock: Treasures in Heaven: Armenian Illuminated Manuscripts. The Morgan Library & Museum, New York; The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1994.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: The Saint John's Bible: A Modern Vision through Medieval Methods
Exhibitions.Textblock: The Saint John's Bible: A Modern Vision through Medieval Methods. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore. 2009.
Illuminated Manuscripts: Masterpieces in Miniature. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1984-1985.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Treasures in Heaven: Armenian Manuscript Illumination
Exhibitions.Textblock: Treasures in Heaven: Armenian Manuscript Illumination. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1988.

Keywords: Codex; Manuscript; Miniature; Original binding; Illumination; Painting; Scripture
Medium: ink and pigments on smooth, yellow paper bound between boards covered with blind-tooled cross and rectangle and the inner boards lined with red silk
Provenance: Napat', Amida, Armenia, early 17th century, by commision; Church of St. Sargis, Amida, Armenia, by gift [date of acquisition unknown]; Henry Walters, Baltimore, [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Amida Gospels
